newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Ex-army chief is new Philippine transport minister.
newsitem.headline: Ex-army chief is new Philippine transport minister.

text.p: Philippine President Fidel Ramos on Sunday appointed former armed forces chief Arturo Enrile as acting transportation and communication secretary.

Enrile replaces businessman Amadeo Lagdameo, who resigned last month after a furore over a land deal with Amari Coastal Bay Development Corp, a joint venture between Centennial City Inc and Ital-Thai Development Plc.

The former general, who retired from the military last year after a two-and-a-half year tenure as chief of staff, was credited with launching reforms in an army linked in the late 1980s to six failed coup attempts against then president Corazon Aquino.

The deal between Amari and the government's Public Estates Authority (PEA) under Lagdameo involves a $1.1 billion project to develop 750 hectares (1,850 acres) of land to be reclaimed from Manila Bay.

Senate president and opposition chief Ernesto Maceda sparked a political row when he alleged last year that a portion of the land to be covered by the deal was grossly underpriced and the transaction was disadvantageous to the government.

Guoco Holdings (Phils) Inc, parent company of Centennial City and a unit of Hong Kong's Guoco Group Ltd, has defended the deal, saying the valuation of 1,250 pesos ($48) per square metre was based on appraisals made by independent firms.
A presidential fact-finding panel said last month the deal was above-board but urged its renegotiation to "correct" certain provisions in the contract.

Lagdameo was not accused of any wrong-doing but the panel said some PEA officials might have benefitted personally from the transaction and urged state prosecutors to conduct a further probe to determine the culpability of any PEA official.
